p: Lavandula angustifolia (Common Lavender, English Lavender, French lavender, Garden Lavender, Lavender) is a flowering plant in the Lamiaceae family. Medicinal parts are usually roots, leaves or fruit of the plants, as well as essential oil from fresh flowers and/or the inflorescence; the flowers collected just before opening and dried, the fresh flowers and the dried flowers. Lavender oil has been reported to contain more than 100 components. The essential oil (1%–3%) of Lavandula is rich in linalool and linalyl acetate. Linalyl acetate is the major compound found in flowers. The plant contains also rosmarinic acid and coumarin (Lis‐Balchin, 2002). Carvacrol (26.2%), limonene (19.6%), 1,8‐cineole (11.8%), terpinen‐4‐ol (7.6%), spathulenol (4.9%), α‐pinene (4.2%), p‐cymene (4.2%), caryophyllene oxide (2.7%) and terpinolene (2.6%) were detected in Lavandula angustifolia essential oil by Bakhsha, Mazandarani, Aryaei, Jafari, & Bayate, 2014.
